title: 104_hr3048
content: The Act may be cited as the "Regulatory Flexibility Amendments Act of 1996". Judicial review is addressed in the Act. The "Regulatory Flexibility Amendments Act of 1996" addresses judicial review, allowing affected small entities to petition for review of final rules that do not have a significant economic impact on them within one year of the rule's effective date. Courts with jurisdiction over rule compliance can review certifications or analyses made by agencies. The "Regulatory Flexibility Amendments Act of 1996" allows affected small entities to petition for judicial review within one year of a final rule's issuance. The term 'affected small entity' refers to those adversely impacted by the rule. Courts can order agencies to prepare a final regulatory flexibility analysis if a certification is found to be arbitrary or not in accordance with the law. The court can order agencies to prepare a final regulatory flexibility analysis if a certification is deemed arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or not in accordance with the law. If the agency fails to comply within a specified period, the court may stay the rule or grant appropriate relief. The court may stay a rule or grant relief if an agency fails to prepare the required analysis or take corrective action. The court must consider the rule of prejudicial error when making any determination. Any regulatory flexibility analysis for a rule will be part of the record for judicial review. This amendment applies to final agency rules issued after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. RULES COMMENTED ON BY SBA CHIEF COUNSEL FOR ADVOCACY. Section 612 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to require agencies to transmit proposed rules and initial regulatory flexibility analysis to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration before publication. The agency must provide an explanation if they determine that an initial regulatory flexibility analysis is not needed for a proposed rule. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy can issue a statement on the rule's impact on small entities within 15 days of receiving the analysis. The agency must publish this statement and their response in the Federal Register for proposed rules. The Federal Register must publish general notice of proposed rulemaking for rules, with a special rule exempting certain proposed rules related to monetary policy or safety of depository institutions. Section 603(a) of title 5, United States Code, is amended accordingly. Congress believes that the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration should have the ability to appear as amicus curiae in court cases reviewing rules.
